body_html:
@Lan1991Xu,

tfdbg CLI has two features that might be useful to you here.

  1. Regular expression search, similar to the Linux less UI. For example, if you want to search for inf and nan, you can scroll to the top with the Home key and then do:
tfdbg> /(inf|nan)

The CLI will try to find inf or nan and if any is found, scroll to the first instance. If any match is found, you can continue to the next ones by using tfdbg> /, just like in less.

  1. You can slice large tensors by using numpy style slicing, e.g.,
tfdbg> pt encoder/conv0/Conv2D:0:DebugIdentity[0, :, :, :]

If you have more questions, let me know.

tfdbg CLI has two features that might be useful to you here.

Regular expression search, similar to the Linux less UI. For example, if you want to search for inf and nan, you can scroll to the top with the Home key and then do:

tfdbg> /(inf|nan)

The CLI will try to find inf or nan and if any is found, scroll to the first instance. If any match is found, you can continue to the next ones by using tfdbg> /, just like in less.

You can slice large tensors by using numpy style slicing, e.g.,

tfdbg> pt encoder/conv0/Conv2D:0:DebugIdentity[0, :, :, :]

If you have more questions, let me know.
body:
@Lan1991Xu,

tfdbg CLI has two features that might be useful to you here.
1) Regular expression search, similar to the Linux `less` UI. For example, if you want to search for `inf` and `nan`, you can scroll to the top with the `Home` key and then do:
```
tfdbg> /(inf|nan)
```
The CLI will try to find `inf` or `nan` and if any is found, scroll to the first instance. If any match is found, you can continue to the next ones by using `tfdbg> /`, just like in `less`.

2) You can slice large tensors by using numpy style slicing, e.g.,
```
tfdbg> pt encoder/conv0/Conv2D:0:DebugIdentity[0, :, :, :]
```

If you have more questions, let me know.
